name: More Dramatic Lives Quiz / Test | People | 10 Questions

questions.text: This playwright had to live with the knowledge that the medication administered to his mother during his birth pushed her into a lifelong problem with drug addiction. This was dramatized in his most famous work.
questions.explanation:
Eugene O'Neill.

	O'Neill's life is honestly and powerfully displayed in 'Long Day's Journey Into Night'. Stark - and sad.

questions.text: This writer was accused of treason and was ultimately hospitalized for mental instability.
questions.explanation:
Ezra Pound.

	Pound was on the wrong side (fascist) in World War II.

questions.text: This poet is said to have been born with a clubfoot.
questions.explanation:
Lord Byron.

	Be that as it may ... he had an interesting life.

questions.text: Writers are told to write from their own first-hand experiences. Nevertheless, this writer wrote about the horror of war before ever seeing combat.
questions.explanation:
Stephen Crane.

	Crane wrote 'The Red Badge of Courage' in this manner. A fine writer -he died quite young.

questions.text: Which writer was NOT hospitalized for mental or emotional problems?
questions.explanation:
Edmund Spenser.

	Spenser - so far as I know - never had the experience. Zelda, Scott's wife (and a minor writer) spent many years in confinement. Cowper also had problems of that sort - as did Clare.

questions.text: Strange as it may seem, it appears that this Elizabethan writer may also have been a spy.
questions.explanation:
Christopher Marlowe.

	Marlowe - who died under unusual circumstances (and thus fueled debate about whether he was really dead AND whether he actually wrote Shakespeare's plays) seems to have been involved as a government agent.

questions.text: This musician had an affair with the legendary George Sand.
questions.explanation:
Chopin.

	He didn't live to reach his 40th birthday.

questions.text: This great thinker and philosopher was castrated for his romantic involvement with a woman.
questions.explanation:
Peter Abelard.

	Abelard got involved with Heloise - much to the fury of certain members of her family. The rest is history - and tragedy.

questions.text: The response to the last novel by this author was so great that he turned his back on fiction and embraced poetry.
questions.explanation:
Thomas Hardy.

	The reaction to 'Jude the Obscure' was unfriendly, which had something of an unnerving effect on Hardy.

questions.text: This writer was placed in jail briefly for refusing to pay a tax
questions.explanation:
Henry David Thoreau.

	It was Thoreau - the man who wrote about 'civil disobedience'
